abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that Project
            Implementation Units (PIUs) create structures parallel to
            those of the government and distort local pay scales. In the
            absence of clear central government commitment to replace
            Bank funds with its own, or the ability of the Fund to
            mobilize funds from international or Georgian donors, the
            Fund is likely to dissolve, and the focus it brings to
            preserving cultural heritage lost. Although scope exists for
            raising funds through entrance fees and through
            contributions of private benefactors, in all countries much
            of the funding for the preservation of cultural heritage
            comes from the government. The Emergency Rehabilitation
            Program proved to be a highly popular approach for
            preserving cultural heritage, and helped to focus the
            nation's attention on both the richness of
            Georgia's legacy and on the need to protect it. People
            whose homes were in poor condition but were not eligible for
            a grant under the Neighborhood Fund Program had difficulty
            understanding why they did not also deserve support. As in
            cities around the world, the investments in Old Town,
            Tbilisi have attracted substantial private investment to
            upgrade historic buildings and to operate shops, cafes,
            restaurants, hotels, and other businesses. Although the
            project included substantial resources for monitoring and
            evaluation, performance indicators were poorly specified,
            and plans for monitoring them could not be implemented.

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Cultural Heritage Project is to improve the management and
            promotion of Georgia's cultural heritage. There are two
            components. The investment component sets up an emergency
            rehabilitation fund that 1) responds to project proposals
            submitted by outside organizations and community groups to
            finance urgent repairs at priority cultural heritage sites,
            important cultural activities, and artifacts at serious
            risk; and 2) finances four cultural heritage pilot sites for
            historic renovation and related activities. The technical
            assistance component 1) strengthens and supports the
            cultural heritage project implementation unit (PIU) in
            project management, finance and administration, procurement,
            monitoring and evaluation, engineering, and other
            specializations; 2) provides training and study tours for
            the PIU, other heritage agencies and institutions, municipal
            government, and community groups involved in the project; 3)
            supports a program of public information, education, and
            communication activities related to cultural heritage
            including seminars, a newsletter, arts and music
            competitions, and oral histories; 4) formulates a blueprint
            to develop cultural heritage zones; and 5) develops a
            management and evaluation system to monitor project impacts
            and performance, which includes technical and financial
            audits, beneficiary assessments, Bank supervision, and
            independent reporting.
